Loses, but its not obvious. This is a very interesting position. Its worth looking at this position in detail, either playing the moves through on the board or trying to visualise the options, to consider which mating threats are most relevant here. Rather than spoil the fun for the reader, I'll provide comments after move 26

Loses, but its not obvious. This is a very interesting position. Its worth looking at this position in detail, either playing the moves through on the board or trying to visualise the options, to consider which mating threats are most relevant here. Rather than spoil the fun for the reader, I'll provide comments after move 26

Not to win the bishop, but to gain a tempo to bring it into the attack on the kingside. Look how blocked white's position is. The advanced black pawns are choking white's defensive plans. Only the white queen and bishop are active, and it will be difficult for them to assist the defence

Not to win the bishop, but to gain a tempo to bring it into the attack on the kingside. Look how blocked white's position is. The advanced black pawns are choking white's defensive plans. Only the white queen and bishop are active, and it will be difficult for them to assist the defence
Consistent, but missing black's intentions

Subtle. White must not be allowed to free his position. Returning to the position at move 24. The options here for black are: 1) Doubled major pieces (q+r) on h file. But this does not work as the white king can escape via g1. 2) Sacrifice of queen on h2, followed by rook check on h file. This does not work as white king can escape via g1. Its clear that g1 needs to be addressed before black's plans can succeed. There are 2 solutions to this. 1) Make white block g1 himself. This is the plan I choose with 27.. e2. or 2) Use the dark square bishop on d4 to attack this square. The problem with idea 2 is the black pawn blocking the diagonal e3-g1, and maybe the white knight that can play to c2 preventing black's plan.  Of course the knight would be overstretched in this scenario, meaning instead black could double on the g file. I think its important at move 24 to be able to visualise all these options as black. And also the classic idea of white r on g1, black p on e2, followed by ..Qxh2+, Kxh2 Rh6 mate
I think white must have missed this idea when he played 24. Qb3. Observe that the black queen needed to be on h4, to prevent Rf2 which would allow white to escape
I think white must have missed this idea when he played 24. Qb3. Observe that the black queen needed to be on h4, to prevent Rf2 which would allow white to escape
Unfortunately black does not get his chance of a nice mate today (the white d pawn obstructs the black rook)
I liked this move. Planning ..Bd4 followed by mate. Moves like 28.. Bxb5 allows white to escape
Only move
Or just ..Bd4 immediately. Although in that line white gets the d7 bishop, and I wanted simplification
White resigns. Black plans .. Qxb7, ..Bxb5, and then some combination of the queen threatening the white knight, the bishop attacking f3, and promotion of the e2 pawn
